text: Hello and welcome.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: This is Active Inference Guest Stream 71.1 on February 22nd, 2024, 2-2-2-2-2-2.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: And we're here with Ryan Smith, Rowan Hodson, and Mariska Mehta.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: There will be a quick overview and then discussion on their recent work, The Empirical Status of Predictive Coding in Active Inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: So thank you all, and let's hear about it.
speaker: SPEAKER_02

text: Okay, so you just want me to jump in and go?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Yeah.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Okay, cool.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Well, thanks a ton, Daniel, for inviting us on.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's fun to get to present some of this stuff and hopefully get it out to the broader community a little bit.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I'm going to quickly just kind of walk through sections of the paper to orient people to generally what the point is and what we're trying to do.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then at that point, I think the goal is just to kind of launch into discussion and see if we can kind of extract out some of the more interesting points that might be most relevant or interesting to the active insurance community.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So just to start out with here, so the paper, as Daniel said, is called The Empirical Status of Predictive Coding and Active Inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The main point of this is just that, as a lot of people in this community know, it's at its kind of beginning and for a long time, like the active inference is primarily, so the literature you'll see has been very focused on theoretical sort of conceptual work.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and simulation-based work, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you'll see a lot of things out there that's kind of, you know, an active inference model of X, where X is just some interesting psychological phenomena or condition.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And usually that involves showing some, you know, fun, interesting simulations that are kind of potential computational explanations for, you know, whatever the specific phenomenon of interest is.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that work is great.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I think there's been a lot of developments there.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But, you know, at a certain point, you know, we can come up with as many theories as we want.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But without actually being able to test them scientifically, it's really hard to be able to say with any confidence that
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: These are kind of accurate stories of what the brain's doing and what are the kind of, yeah, again, like empirically supported theory, you know, which of all these different sort of models and simulations people are proposing sort of actually correspond to what the brain's doing and whether they can actually explain human behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So what we were interested in doing is actually kind of taking a step back and looking at what the empirical studies that have been done using these sorts of modeling approaches, what they actually say, and how supportive the evidence actually is for, you know, the hypothesis that the brain is doing things like predictive coding and active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that's why it's called the empirical status, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: As we're trying to say, okay, what is the current evidence and where is evidence missing, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So what should future work and future studies focus on to try to actually like fill in and answer questions and provide additional support or not for these theories as hypotheses for what the brain is doing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Um, so to kind of walk you through sections here, so we focused, you know, so people use this umbrella term of like predictive processing, but that's really a fairly vague overarching kind of umbrella term.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so we picked the primary, actually well-defined algorithms that are most prominent under the predictive processing umbrella, which is predictive coding and active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: These are well-defined mathematical algorithms that can be sufficiently precise to test empirically.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So the first section is more or less just an introduction that says,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: more or less the sort of thing I just said about predictive coding and active inference being the kind of most prominent, precisely formulated algorithms that the brain might be doing and the importance of testing these things empirically, et cetera, et cetera.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so I should say that most of the credit for this paper should really go to the first author, which is Rowan Hodson here, who I'm hoping will certainly say much more after I give this kind of brief overview.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But so what Rowan did is he started out
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: in each of these sections by defining the algorithm and laying out the associated mathematics in a way that was really very clear, I thought.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Of course, I'm bragging a little bit about a paper that I'm on, so take that with a grain of salt.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But I thought he did a very good job of laying it out, being explicit, showing the mathematics, but describing it in a way that was
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: what I think should be very accessible to people that don't have a ton of mathematical background.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the idea was that we would just, you know, introduce this so that what we were talking about was clear, but the focus really isn't on, you know, just the mathematics.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We're just introducing a mathematics so it can be kind of more understandable what, you know, what the studies that we review are actually testing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so we just kind of walk through a lot of that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I'll come back to this figure in a second.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: but the underlying mathematics of, for instance, here is a definition of the negative free energy when applied within predictive coding and just kind of how you get to some of the predictions and prediction errors and things like that that we actually use.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this figure is a figure that took a long time to make and to try to be clear on, but we thought it ended up being pretty colorful and engaging.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It looks complicated, but we tried pretty hard to kind of walk people through step by step what this is hypothesizing.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But this is just a representation of one way that cortical columns in the brain might implement hierarchical predictive coding.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this is a particular form of a particular predictive coding algorithm that allows first a certain type of temporal depth to it, where you have
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: essentially a higher level hidden cause that's being represented that actually predicts dynamics in the representations at the level below, as opposed to just predicting and trying to minimize prediction error with respect to some sort of static equivalent temporal scale representation at the level below.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we try to kind of lay that out so that people have an understanding of what, again, what the kind of general basis and what the hypothesis is.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's kind of important here because predictive coding at an algorithmic level is a different thing to test than trying to test a theory about the specific neural mechanisms
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: that implement predictive coding.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I think it's a really important point.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: This is that you can test a theory empirically by looking at the brain to try to test a hypothesis about a specific way the brain could be set up to do predictive coding.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But the brain could be set up in more than one way that would implement predictive coding.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So to be specific about testing something about the brain process, you need to specify
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: what algorithm you want to see, whether there's evidence that the brain is doing that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: More generally, though, you could also just test for evidence of predictive coding at the algorithmic level.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And you could do that behaviorally just by looking at what people detect perceptually and how that evolves over time, whether that is just consistent with the predictive coding algorithm.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So just the mathematics, not some more specific hypothesis about the way the brain is doing it through different patterns of connectivity.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Um, so then, uh, as I mentioned, we kind of go through, um, now just, uh, we lay out what they propose neural implementation is, or as I said, one commonly proposed implementation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's actually a couple that we talk about.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Um, and then here in this section, we have the empirical studies of predictive coding, and we review more or less what the evidence is.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: for these different, for different kind of aspects or testing different predictions that predictive coding might make about what you would see either behaviorally or in the brain.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And I won't kind of go into it in detail here.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can obviously talk about it when we get more into the discussion, but, you know, take-home is,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Really, there is a lot of indirect evidence, but there's a lot of studies that still kind of remain to be done to test more specific hypotheses about the neural implementation.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: whether or not, for example, there actually are separate neurons in the brain that are responding just to prediction errors and other ones that are representing just predictions and things like that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There really is more kind of explicit model fitting that needs to be done to test out predictions associated with quantitative simulations and what those predict based on the predictive coding algorithm.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: One place where probably
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The most kind of related evidence is not with predictive coding proper, but with hierarchical Gaussian filter, which is a different model than predictive coding.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But it has related.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It predicts dynamics that are related to predictive coding.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So for instance, it does have prediction errors in it, and it does have a precision weighting on those predictions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And the updates can be modeled in relation to prediction errors.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: One difference though is instead of being hierarchical in the sense of each level in a hierarchy representing different causes in the hierarchical Gaussian filter, higher levels represent predictions about the stability of the contingencies at the level below.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So basically, the highest level is representing something like how quickly it expects the predictive relationships between hidden states and outcomes, how quickly it expects those will change over time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so it can do this kind of dynamic precision weighting, depending on essentially how much you should trust the predictions you have in a given moment based on how you think those predictive relationships will change over time.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it's not the same thing as predictive coding, but it's related.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And people have done neuroimaging studies, for example,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and looked at the explicit relationship between the prediction aerodynamics that this model, the predictions it makes about those prediction and prediction aerodynamics, and whether or not you can find neural responses that look like they match those predicted simulated time courses.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And there haven't been a few studies that do support that specific brain regions are encoding prediction errors and predictions and things like that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: and different precisions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it's not the same thing as testing predictive coding directly, but it is testing and finding evidence for a neural basis of encoding of precision-weighted prediction errors, which again, overlaps in interesting ways as kind of again, indirect, but important evidence.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So then after we go through that, then we switch to talking about active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And again, kind of similar structure.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: First, Rowan introduced the mathematics associated with the Active Inference Framework.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And for people that are watching the Active Inference Institute program regularly should be aware that Active Inference nowadays has evolved into
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: kind of also being a broader umbrella term for multiple different specific mathematical formalisms.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so to be clear, this one that we go through here is just the kind of standard initial partially observable Markov decision process framework.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So this is a specific model of decision-making based on a particular explore exploit trade-off in a model-based way.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: where instead of just using reward as a cost function or an objective function, it's based on the expected free energy, which is just this combination of expected reward and expected information gain.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So it's talking about a specific algorithm and the original algorithm under active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But now there's lots of different variants of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we're just going through the basic one.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So again, we talk about how it's related to predictive coding and what's different about it from predictive coding.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then in this case, what we do is there is actually quite a bit more in active inference, at least this version of it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There are a number of empirical studies that have directly fit active inference models to decision making behavior.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: Several of these come out of our lab, actually, but there are some other ones that haven't.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so we reviewed each of these in detail, kind of laid out how the models were set up to model specific decision-making or perceptual decision-making tasks.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You know, so for instance, here we kind of introduced the model for a specific task we used to model interoception, so cardiac interoception.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then, yeah, here you can just see this is just kind of a standard, you know, version of a depiction of the active inference model.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And then, let's see, you know, again,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: These are sort of standard things you see in lots of active inference papers, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So just describing and laying out the mathematics of the general update equations and the overall algorithm, and then a very kind of coarse-grained, generic sort of representation of one way that the brain might implement those algorithms, kind of inspired by cortical column structure.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But so anyway, you can see this is a model that we used to, an active inference model we set up to model a three-armed bandit task that we used in substance use disorders to show that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And in this one, what we were able to show, for example, was that substance users showed slower learning rates from negative outcomes than healthy individuals.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So you could see it's much more based on trying to answer psychiatric questions about clinical groups, because our lab is focused on computational psychiatry.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: in particular.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we walked through that.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We walked through a task that we modeled using an approach avoidance conflict paradigm.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And that model also was able to show differences in decision uncertainty and what we called emotion conflict.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's a type of preference precision effectively that also differed in affective disorders and substance use disorders from healthy controls in an interesting way.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There was also a couple others.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: One really cool study that was not by us, but by Gidgson was the first author.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And they took, for example, a set of publicly available data sets for what's called a two-step task, which is just a common task used in reinforcement learning models.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And in that task, there's a standard reinforcement learning model that's used that's essentially kind of a mixture-based model of what a model-free reinforcement learning model versus a model-based reinforcement learning model would predict.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And what that task was designed to do initially was to use this kind of mixture reinforcement learning model to test individual differences in how kind of model-based versus model-free people are.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: We can talk about that a little more if people listening aren't totally familiar with the model-based versus model-free distinction.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: But what they did, which was really cool, was they took that data and fit an active inference model to it and then compared the ability of active inference to explain behavior compared to the standard reinforcement learning model I just mentioned.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And what they were able to show is that the active inference model
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: in two of the four datasets was actually a little bit better at explaining the behavioral patterns than the reinforcement learning model was.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: In the other two datasets, the models were about equivalent.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that was probably the most direct evidence that has been shown.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And this was one of the major points I think that we wanted to make is that even though it's the case that us and other people have started to do actual empirical studies trying to fit active inference models to data,
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: The main purpose so far and what people have done really hasn't been to provide unique evidence for active inference.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's just been using active inference as a way to try to identify individual differences or group differences in a psychiatric research context.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So one thing that is still really needed
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: aside from this one Gitchin study I mentioned, is more studies where people actually take behavioral data or collect behavioral data on decision making tasks and fit a bunch of fit different active inference models to it and also fit a bunch of sort of competing models like reinforcement learning models to it.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: to really show that the behavioral patterns that active inference can do a better job of predicting that behavior than competing models can.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: because that's really the only way.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: It's not enough basically to show that active inference models fit well.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: You need to show that active inference models fit better than competing models, because that's how you'd really show that active inference is more likely what the brain is doing when people are making decisions.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: And so, you know, the overarching conclusion is that, you know, the evidence is promising, right?
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: I mean, there's nothing that suggests that the brain isn't doing active inference, and certainly it's consistent with people using active inference, but a lot more still needs to be done to show that active inference is a better explanation for what people do than simpler competing models.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So that's, you know, just as a kind of broad, brief overview of the general structure of the paper and the message we were trying to get across.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So, you know, we can certainly talk about it more just kind of interactively now.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: There's lots that I didn't talk about, but hopefully that starts as just kind of an initial launching point for discussion.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So I guess I'll just stop there.
speaker: SPEAKER_00

speaker: SPEAKER_00

text: So we can ask people to do, say, some kind of sequential decision-making task that involves usually explore-exploit dynamics of some form.
